One can leverage these phenomena in two broad classes of experiments to interrogate porosity: inert gas physisorption and porosimetry. Physisorption is generally useful for characterizing microporosity (∼0.3–2.0 nm), mesoporosity (2.0–5.0 nm), and macroporosity up to ∼ 50 nm [146], whereas porosimetry is useful for characterizing pore structures ∼ 10 nm-150 μm, which are commonly encountered in pelletized or extruded materials [147]. Gas physisorption : Generally, physisorption experiments involve collecting N2, Ar, or CO2 adsorption and desorption isotherms. The choice of adsorbate depends on the material considered and the properties interrogated [148]. More strongly interacting molecules are also suitable for characterization when the situation dictates, though interpretation of the isotherm is generally more nuanced in these cases [149,150]. N2 is the most widely used adsorbent, and N2 physisorption isotherms are usually analyzed in the context of BET and Kelvin pore adsorption theories, which provide a generalized method for characterizing porosity [151,152]. N2 physisorption allows a reasonable determination of surface area, total pore volume, average pore diameter, and pore size distributions for most materials; however, its polarizability complicates micropore analysis for materials such as zeolites, carbons, and MOFs [153]. For micropore characterization, Ar and O2 are preferred adsorbates as they have smaller quadrupole moments than N2 and so provide a more reliable determination of micropore surface area. Ar and O2 can otherwise be used to probe the same material properties as N2 [154]. While it is infrequently used compared to N2 physisorption, there are few drawbacks to using Ar as an adsorbate. Ar physisorption can be performed at either liquid N2 (77 K) or liquid Ar (87 K) temperatures, but the use of liquid Ar as a cryostat is preferred as it will give the same pore distribution coverage as the analogous N2 physisorption experiment. A minor disadvantage is that Ar and liquid Ar are marginally more difficult and expensive to source than N2 analogs, but the method is usually accessible for most laboratories. Physisorption experiments rely on barometric data: that is, they record the pressure of a gas phase of known volume that is in equilibrium with a solid sample held at constant temperature. Changes in the gas phase pressure in response to dosing and uptake of an adsorbate are then used to determine the molar quantity of gas adsorbed. This approach is constrained by the ability to resolve changes in pressure that arise from gas adsorption. Total gas uptake scales with surface area, so most instruments require a minimum total solid surface area (∼5 m2) to allow for detectable pressure changes and reproducible analysis. Sample cells will generally accommodate maximum solid loadings of ∼ 1 g, so it can be challenging to interrogate low surface area materials (i.e., ≲ 5 m2/g) by conventional physisorption of N2 or Ar [155]. If sample or system properties prevent one from achieving a total surface area of ∼ 5 m2, then one should instead consider Kr adsorption at liquid N2 temperatures for surface area determination [156]. CO2 is not strictly an inert gas—it has acidic character, and it will bind at basic surface sites like O2– in solid oxides. As such, CO2 adsorption is less of a general-purpose experiment. That said, CO2 physisorption at 273 K is a viable alternative for porosity analysis in microporous carbons [157]. For these materials, the kinetics of N2 and Ar physisorption at cryogenic temperatures are slow, resulting in long equilibration times and protracted physisorption experiments. As isotherms are only reliable if data reflect equilibrium uptake at a given titrant pressure, slow physisorption introduces considerable variability. In these cases, CO2 physisorption at near-ambient temperature provides a reliable method for interrogating micropore structures. With proper experimental protocols, any of these three adsorbate molecules (N2, Ar, or CO2) can be used to build a comprehensive understanding of a material’s pore structure [158]. Physisorption isotherms are most informative when they include uptake data from very low relative pressure—P/P 0 ∼ 10-6 for microporous materials or P/P 0 ∼ 10-3 for meso- or non-porous samples—up to the saturation pressure of the adsorbate at the temperature where the isotherm is collected, P/P 0 ∼ 1. Accurate measurement of data at these low-pressure ranges requires proper degassing of the samples, which generally entails heating under vacuum, and may require surprisingly long degas times for samples with extensive microporosity [159]. Furthermore, one can obtain a more complete description of material properties by collecting both adsorption and desorption branches of the isotherm. Specifically, inert gas adsorption and desorption isotherms often show hysteresis. That is to say, the adsorption and desorption processes follow different paths on a graph of gas uptake against relative pressure. Evaluation of hysteresis and other differences in adsorption and desorption branches can reveal important details about the pore structure of a material [160]. The BET method of isotherm analysis has been the gold standard of surface area measurement for nearly 90 years [161]. While the use of BET and other Kelvin equation-derived theories (e.g., Barrett, Joyner, and Halenda (BJH)) is commonplace and built into analysis software for commercial physisorption instruments, significant variation of results from different laboratories is both possible and observed [65]. Users of the BET theory are urged to understand the numerous assumptions that are made [162], to check if the automated fits are appropriate for your data [163], and to use consistency criterion for evaluation of BET-derived parameters [164]. Intuition is also important in model use: when using appropriate models and P/P 0 regions, one should expect to find measured values that align with well-established benchmarks from the literature. For example, HK (Horvath–Kawazoe) analysis of N2 or Ar adsorption isotherms should return average pore diameters of ∼ 0.6 nm for MFI zeolites. By contrast, BET analysis of N2 uptake isotherms for hexagonal mesoporous silicas (HMS), such as MCM-41, should return a surface area of ∼ 1000 m2/g [165]. More modern methods based on nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) seek to overcome the limitations of classical theory by using semi-empirical models to determine molecular interaction potentials but they require substantial kernel development [166], although many are available with vendor software [167]. Porosimetry and pyncnometry : Macropore analysis is necessary for a complete description of the porosity and bulk density. This is especially true for pelletized materials that are used in industrial catalysis as they often have pore features on μm-mm length scales. Gas physisorption techniques described in the preceding section are limited to pores smaller than ∼ 50 nm. For macropores larger than 10 nm and up to 150 μm, a complimentary technique – Hg porosimetry – can be used to interrogate the pore structure [147,151]. Hg porosimetry is an intrusion method governed by the Washburn equation that describes the force required to push a non-wetting fluid into a capillary: (6) D = - 4 γ cos θ P where D is the cylindrical analogue pore diameter, γ is the surface tension, θ is the contact angle, and P is the applied pressure. Through the Washburn equation, the intrusion into a pore of a given size is inversely proportional to the pressure applied. Unlike gas physisorption, which relies on capillary condensation for pore sizing and is therefore limited to micro/mesopore sizes, Hg porosimetry can directly assess the pore diameter of pores at the meso-macro scale [168,169]. The toxicity of Hg has made this a technique that is problematic in many laboratories, as spent materials always contain residual Hg in the pores. Reports detail other options and methods [170], and a standard using H2O is available [171]. The determination of true skeletal density by He pycnometry [172] or envelope density by powder pycnometry [173] can be used in combination with porosimetry to provide pore volume analysis. 2.2.2 Particle size distributions Cases of structure sensitivity are well-documented [47], so the size and morphology (e.g., shape) of catalytic domains are important physical properties. It is worth visualizing that the size of the active domain (e.g., a metal nanoparticle) is a different concept from grain size (e.g., a zeolite crystal), which is itself a different concept from the macroscale dimensions of a pelletized material. Each of these domain sizes may influence various aspects of catalyst performance. While variations in the size and shape of metal nanoparticles comprise the classic notion of structure sensitivity, variations in grain sizes or pellet diameters will alter rates of intraparticle and interphase heat and mass transfer. One might also imagine that variations in grain or pellet size may be crucial to achieving workable pressure gradients in large industrial reactors. Ideally, each of these physical dimensions should be characterized and described in publications. Particle Size Distributions at the Length Scale of the Active Site : Insights from surface science reveal that different metal facets may have different catalytic functions. Often, activity is associated with rare, high-energy corner, edge, or defect sites as opposed to the low index terrace sites that comprise the majority of metal surfaces in large nanoparticles and bulk structures. Conversely, reactivity may be associated with sparse binding sites at metal-support interfaces, as in the case of low-temperature water gas shift [174]. Because interfacial area scales inversely with metal particle size, one might observe that turnover frequencies are influenced by metal dispersion. For these reasons, many reactions should be considered “structure-sensitive” and dependent on both the shape and size of metal particles. It is then important to acknowledge that the shape and size of metal nanoparticles in a typical catalyst is almost certainly non-uniform. In most catalysts, one expects that particle size and structure will vary spatially throughout the catalyst sample. If one accepts that reactions can be size- and structure-sensitive, then one also should expect spatial heterogeneity in reaction rates throughout catalyst pellets. Accordingly, one must not only characterize and report the average size and/or shape of a particle, but also the particle size distribution and heterogeneity in the active phase. The most common method for obtaining a metal particle size distribution is electron microscopy. For particles at the micron scale, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and atomic force microscopy (AFM) can be informative. That said, metal catalysis generally occurs on particles between 1 and 50 nm, which makes scanning and/or transmission electron microscopies (S/TEM) the methods of choice for quantifying the particle size distributions that are most relevant in catalysis. It is worth mentioning that X-ray diffraction, especially with synchrotron-based methods or modern high sensitivity detectors, is now able to detect crystalline domains down to ∼ 1 nm, and peak location/width in diffraction patterns can be used to estimate average metal particle sizes [113,114]; however, XRD patterns provide no information about particle size distribution and heterogeneity [175–177]. It is challenging to sample a representative set of dispersed metal nanoparticles particles with electron microscopy. As an example, consider a hypothetical catalyst that contains 1 wt% of hemispherical Pt nanoparticles that have an average diameter of 10 nm and are dispersed onto a high surface area support. The total number of Pt particles found in 1 μg of sample – on the order of one billion – can be estimated from the following equation: (7) N = 12 Wt . % m cat π ρ Pt D Pt 3 = 12 1 / 100 10 - 6 g π 21.4 g cc 10 n m 3 ∼ O 10 9 Even with modern automated sampling and counting methods, it is impossible to randomly sample enough particles from this set to obtain a “true” particle size distribution. Moreover, defining a particle size distribution always requires the user to make decisions about how to bin and count particles, which can lead to varied results as multiple users analyze identical micrographs [178]. This uncertainty makes it challenging to, for example, discern mechanisms for sintering that underly catalyst deactivation [179]. Because characterizing a particle size distribution with microscopy is sensitive to specific particles imaged and to choices made by the practitioner, it is important to fully describe the manor and method for obtaining metal particle size distributions. As a final note, one often considers gas titration of metal surfaces—CO or H2 chemisorption on Pt for example—to be the gold standard for quantitative determination of exposed metal surface area; however, some metal catalysts are not amenable to straightforward titration methods. In these cases, particle size distributions obtained from microscopy can be used to estimate the accessible metal surface area. This is common practice for gold catalysts and bimetallic alloys, which either lack a reliable chemisorption method or, especially in the case of alloys, may have a poorly defined active site altogether. These surface area calculations are dependent on the determination of a particle size distribution, so they are subject to the same statistical challenges outlined above; as such, reporting recommendations extend to metal surface areas inferred from electron microscopy, and practitioners should report calculations and assumptions used in the generating the particle size distribution and estimating metal surface area from it. Grain sizes (and distributions) of the bulk catalyst: Beyond the size and distribution of the active phase, the dimensions of the bulk catalyst particle (or pellet) are important to consider as they determine the length scales of diffusion/conduction between the bulk fluid and the active material dispersed throughout the catalyst pellet. In general, larger particles will have larger gradients in temperature and/or species concentration between the center of the pellet and the bulk fluid. In contrast, beds comprised of smaller pellets will have larger pressure gradients. For these reasons, consideration of catalyst macrostructure is critical to reproducibility, especially with engineered materials used in industrial practice. Average grain sizes for powders are relatively easy to determine using sieves [180]. These should generally be reported as part of the catalyst synthesis/testing protocols as they aid in assessing the extent of heat and/or mass transfer limitations. Laser techniques are more sophisticated methods can be utilized to determine particle size distributions at the macroscale (i.e., cm) [181,182]. 3 Perspectives and conclusion Bulk characterization methods are among the most ubiquitous, practical, and cost-effective techniques available to catalysis practitioners at universities, national laboratories, and industrial research centers. The aggregate property information provided by these methods offers reliable and vital insight into structural and chemical attributes of a catalyst, which are needed to rationalize its kinetic behavior and understand its macroscopic performance. Bulk characterization data are commonly reported in the catalysis literature; unfortunately, catalyst preparation, instrument calibration, control experiments, data analysis, and technique limitations are not always described in sufficient detail to permit experimental replication and data verification. This oversight makes it challenging to compare results obtained from different laboratories or by using different synthetic protocols, which in turn hinders proper benchmarking of catalyst performance. It is imperative that we, as a community, establish best practices and standards for execution and accurate reporting of bulk characterization data. Doing so will allow us to properly archive knowledge, identify potential origins of inexplicable or irreproducible behavior, and meaningfully interpret differences in catalyst performance. In this perspective we discuss many useful and widely practiced characterization methods that can be used to assess essential bulk catalyst properties. These methods allow one to interrogate composition, structure, oxidation state, coordination environment, porosity, and particle/grain size distributions. A summary of key takeaways has been condensed into a set of best practices in procedure and reporting (Table 2 ). We reiterate that this information is not intended to be prescriptive. Our motivation is to encourage catalysis researchers, particularly new entrants in the field, to fully report detailed descriptions of materials and methods along with benchmarking of experimental protocols in their publications to aid in improving rigor and reproducibility in catalysis science. coredata.dc:description: Bulk characterization of a solid provides us with a spatially-averaged description of its physical and chemical properties. These properties are not site-specific, but they are critical for categorizing materials and understanding their catalytic performance. Important bulk chemical properties include elemental composition, crystal structure, atomic coordination environment, and the oxidation states of elements comprising the catalyst. Significant physical properties include accessible surface area, pore volume, pore diameter, and particle size distributions that exist at the various length scales of catalysis. Each physicochemical property is sensitive to the conditions employed for catalyst synthesis, storage, pre-treatment, activation, and characterization. Thus, it is imperative that authors fully describe materials and methods in publications as this metadata provides context for observed phenomena and allows others to recreate the exact conditions that are essential for reproducibility. Such protocols are necessary for a meaningful interpretation of differences in catalyst performance observed across laboratories. This perspective article defines bulk characterization, provides guidance on bulk characterization methods, and emphasizes important considerations and best practices. Our aim is to build a more nuanced understanding of catalyst characterization. We hope that awareness and application of the principles outlined herein will improve rigor and reproducibility in catalysis science.
coredata.dc:title: Best practices in the characterization of bulk catalyst properties
